content:
With the math template for lake new, starting a new Mathlib-based project is straightforward. Would it make sense to have a similar cslib template for CSLib?

This would allow users to run something like:

lake new my-cslib-project cslib

to get a project pre-configured with CSLib as a dependency.

Is there interest in this? If so, I'd be happy to look into what it would take to implement and open an issue/PR on the Lean4 repo.

My thought is that it is simple enough to add CSLib as a dependency the standard way via the lakefile. I don't think we need to ask core to add any special support. I would however welcome a PR adding a section to our README explaining how to add CSLib as a dependency.

Chris Henson said:

My thought is that it is simple enough to add CSLib as a dependency the standard way via the lakefile. I don't think we need to ask core to add any special support. I would however welcome a PR adding a section to our README explaining how to add CSLib as a dependency.

Sounds good. I was also on the fence about this one; appreciate the guidance. Here we are: https://github.com/leanprover/cslib/pull/206 .
Just wanted to resuscitate this: it'd have helped me this week with two logician colleagues, and I'd expect it'd be helpful with applied math students as well.
I created an rfc on lean core for this: Following lean contribution guidelines, I have created an RFC issue lean4#12592
If you show support on the thread and thumbs up react on the issue, a PR is more likely to succeed per the template

Chris Henson said:

My thought is that it is simple enough to add CSLib as a dependency the standard way via the lakefile. I don't think we need to ask core to add any special support. I would however welcome a PR adding a section to our README explaining how to add CSLib as a dependency.

There are lots of computer scientists who donâ€™t have to use a computer beyond latex(overleaf) and the internet. What they do is essentially just mathematics. Even touching the CLI can be asking too much. Following these instructions is not going to be simple. They might contribute theorems about expander graphs or game theory but struggle with these instructions.

It's really beyond my purview at this point. If core accepts this and it makes things easier for this target audience, that is good. I maintain my position from the technical perspective of uniform usage of lake, but perhaps this is a bit myopic with respect to this target audience.
lake usage is not uniform at all. Currently we have a whole separate workflow for math projects.

Yes, I understand that. My point is that you are proposing to add another exception of the same flavor. It is not my decision, but I personally don't care for this.

However, as I have expressed above, your points about it being a small strictly additive feature that could help this sort of user have ultimately convinced me at least partially.
To all : If you agree with the change, please give a thumbs up on the issue. It indicates how many people want it, and if cslib leads and maintainers like it, that makes a stronger case.
My guess is that a PR would be welcome here too, on the premise that the main sticking point of this RFC will be the absence of any time for someone on the FRO to implement it.
